Illustrative Example: Using a PivotTable

In this illustrative example, a data set is used to illustrate creating a PivotTable in Excel.


The Data Set


We use a survey data set to illustrate the use of a PivotTable. This survey is conducted in four out of ten of these villages shown below. The aim of the survey is to determine variables that affect the yield of rice. There are five other variables in the resulting data set from the survey: village, field, size, fertiliser, and variety.

  • Village is the village where the survey was performed: This survey looks at four villages - Nanda, Sabey, Kesen, Niko.
  • Field is the field within a village where the crop was grown.
  • Size is a measurement of the field size in acres.
  • Fertiliser is the fertiliser amount. This is a numerical variable.
  • Variety is the type of variety of rice - there are three varieties: Old, New, and Traditional.


Inserting a Pivot Table

First, highlight the data from the data frame that you want to display in the Pivot Table, including the column headings. In general, this would usually be the entire data frame.


Then, open the Pivot Table option. This location depends on the spreadsheet being used. For two common spreadsheet software:

  • In Excel, this is under Insert > Pivot Table
  • In Google Sheets, it is under the Data menu.


Then we can just click to insert the Pivot Table. It is recommended to insert it as a new sheet.



Configuring the table

Once the pivot table sheet is opened, there is typically a window with four fields: Columns, Rows, Values, Filters.

The variables from your data selection can be dragged and dropped into the appropriate fields in this window. We will go through these four fields now.



Columns and Rows: Rearranging the Pivot Table

We can move variables from Columns to Rows and vice versa. What happens to variables inputted in “Columns”? And how about for “Rows”?



Values: Gaining Summary Statistics

Drag the variable(s) to summarise into the Values field. In this example, this is the outcome variable, yield.

In our example, using “Sum” doesn’t make much sense. What does the sum of yield mean? We can change to a more appropriate summary statistic. We can change the summaries displayed by clicking on the value in the field, and explore this variable by changing the summary statistics.



Filter: Subsetting the data

We can refine the analysis by excluding or including specific values or ranges, such as a range of dates, factor levels, or within certain numerical ranges.

Refresh: Updating the table

If the data in the data sheet changes, you can refresh the pivot table to update the summaries. In Excel, you can do this under PivotTable Analyse > Refresh
